And I gotta tell you people, I didn't have any kind of relationship with Monica whatsoever, unless you want to count the fact that she held up my children's inheritance for fifteen years. I guess we're just supposed to forget about all that now. And I am more than willing. But the perso n you should be calling is Emily Morrison, who was Monica's friend and is the person who has been dealing with all of this in New York. But it has nothing to do with me. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 90 CONTINUED: 90 EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well-thank you all for coming. WOMAN MOURNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for doing this, Emily. THE MOURNERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you, Emily. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you all know, Monica was not a religious woman. Anybody who ever had to sit through a wedding or a funeral with her knows how she felt about formal occasions. So Harry and Elise and I, when we were talking about this, decided we would just have everyone over and let.anyone who wanted to.talk. about Monica just talk about her. Maybe share some remembrances of her. Some of us know each other, some of us don't. But we're all here because we loved Monica. (She stops. Gets a hold of herself) And  because we want to pay tribute to her in a way that might conceivably not enrage her. Everyone laughs slightly. EMILY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to tell anyone what to think, or how to feel. And I don't want to kid myself about the stupid, meaningless way she died, because it would really make her throw up. But I don't want it to become the summation of her life. Because it's not. When her Lisa died I said to her, "How can you stand it?" And she said. "First of all I can't. But I don't want to take away the twelve years she did have, and turn them all into leukemia. Because they weren't." So despite the fact that she got -- ripped off, I do think it's important to remember that Monica got a lot out of life. She was the most fully developed person I personally have ever known. She was also impossible to get along with, but that's another story. Everybody laughs.  EMILY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As most of you know, she had more than her share of trouble over the years. But that never diminished her compassion or stopped her from embracing life to the absolute fullest -- measure.

dialogues.text: Karl, I was supposed to call them last week. You said you were gonna call her and you didn't. So then I called her, and she never called me back. So what do you want me to do? KARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, you know what? I want to talk about  this, not right now.  ANNETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and if there's anything she can't eat and they put it in the hampers, she's not gonna have anything to eat. The last time  she came out here we went to three different places and she couldn't eat anything on the menu. KARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to ask her. I will. We're right in the middle of something. ANNETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Tell her I said hi. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? KARL (TO LISA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa puts a new cowboy hat in her luggage. She tries to z the bag but it won't zip. (This is a dream)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa is asleep. The room is dark. She stirs. She realizes JOAN is sitting on the edge of her bed, her back to Lisa. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom? What's wrong?...Did you have a bad show? What time is it?. Joan starts coughing. Blood starts coming out with every cough, first a little, then a gruesome amount -- LISA WAKES UP -- breathing hard short breaths. The room i dark and quiet. She calms down and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revised 10/9/05 - Page 81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes in without turning on the light. She turns on t faucet. In the dim bathroom the water looks strangely dar She switches on the light -- BLOOD is streaming out the faucet and filling the basin. She looks up. MONICA the dead woman is standing behind he the mirror. Lisa jumps --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa wakes up sharply, breathing hard, drenched in sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dials Maretti's number. It rings... MARETTI (ON PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? (Pause) Hello...? She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: . SUBWAY, (MOVING)
dialogues.text: Lisa rides the subway past Brooklyn stations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa emerges from the subway station. The Verrazano Narro Bridge dominates the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa turns the unfamiliar corner. Little kids play in the street. She checks the address on the piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rings the doorbell. Inside she hears kids playing. Th door opens. It's MRS MARETTI, around 35. MRS MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, can help you? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm sorry to bother you. My name is Lisa Cohen. I was involved in the same accident that Mr Maretti was involved in a few weeks ago... MRS MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, were you? Oh my God, what a thing, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 108 CONTINUED: 108 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...I was just wondering if I could talk to him fora minute. Is he home? MRS MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummmmm, yeah, sure. Whyn't you come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa follows Mrs Maretti into the small apartment. O.C. w HEAR two small BOYS running around and shouting. MARETTI watching TV. Mrs Maretti goes over and speaks to him, low sees LISA and slowly gets up. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm really sorry to bother you...We never met. My name is Lisa Cohen... MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...What can I do for you?  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...do you remember me? From the bus accident? MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.. .What' s this about? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, would it be OK if I talked to you for a minute? MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to talk about? I don't understand. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd just like to talk about the accident for a minute. I don't want anything, and I'm not here to do anything bad. I just wanted to talk to you about it. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get my address? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in the phone book. I was gonna call first... MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it woulda been better if you woulda  called. We're about to sit down... Mrs Maretti has drifted back toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revised 10/9/05 - Page 83 109 CONTINUED: 109 MARETTI (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get what, uh...Yeah all right. Let's go outside. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry: Could I use your bathroom? MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, let's just go outside. MRS MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right over there, honey. (turning) Will you kids settle down, please! I'm not kiddin'! Lisa goes in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MARETTI MRS MARETTI
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you? Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: MARETTI MRS MARETTI
dialogues.text: She's some girl who was at the Nothin's the matter with m accident -- let her use the fuckin' bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa latches the door of the cluttered little bathroom. S sits on the toilet and tries to pee. After a minute a tin amount of pee comes out.

dialogues.speaker: -INT. THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Lisa comes out. The Marettis are waiting for her as befor O.C., we hear the boys yelling at each other.

dialogues.text: Maretti, Mrs Maretti, and Lisa come out. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to MRS MARETTI) Honey, just do me a favor, wait inside. MRS MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I wanna hear what this is. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ...If it's OK, I'd rather talk to Mr Maretti in private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revised 10/9/05 - Page 84 112 CONTINUED: 112 MRS MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not OK. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. We're just tryin' to...OK: What? Lisa looks at them, wishing Mrs Maretti would leave. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. I hope this isn't going to insult you too much... MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Insult me...?  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .I was just wondering if you felt bad at  all about what happened.  MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I feel bad about the accident?  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. MRS MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, honey? Are you just upset about the accident...? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! I'm upset about the accident! I'm very

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: upset about the accident! I was covered in blood! I've never been covered in blood  before, and I wanted to talk to you about  it for a minute! Why is that so strange!? MRS MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry... why don't we all go inside and sit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: down? LISA (ON "WHY")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I please talk to you alone? MRS MARETTI. OK, what is goin' on here? MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin's goin' on here. So whyn't you calm down? Look: Go ahead inside. Let me find out what this is. Meantime whyn't you make sure those kids aren't killin' each other, all right? MRS MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revised 10/9/05 - Page 84A 112 CONTINUED: (2) 112

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mrs Maretti goes inside: MARETTI (MORE JOVIALLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you know what? Let 'em kill each other. Give us all a rest. (To LISA) All right, Lisa. What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just...Well, I just want you to know... MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... you probably already know, obviously, that I told-the police on the police report that I thought the whole, thing was an accident... MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Right. Because it was an accident. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I mean, I know you didn't do it on purpose. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On purpose...?  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it wasn't like...  MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. (Pause) Speak. Talk! What! LISA

dialogues.text: Romantically...! LISA

dialogues.text: I am -- MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't drag me outta my house on a Saturday afternoon and then make me stand here pullin' teeth to find out what you're talkin' about. (MORE)

dialogues.text: I've got my kids inside: You're an attractive young lady, you show up at the  house -- Please! Get to the point or go home. Because I don't care enough, frankly,  to stand around here tryin' to figure out  what you're doin' here! (Pause) What! What!  What! What! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! Well...the way I remember the accident is that you were wearing this cowboy hat -- MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's my cowboy hat that I wear sometimes to amuse myself on the bus, yes. I was probably wearing my cowboy hat, yes. What. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could just let me...! From my point of view, I was out that day trying to buy a cowboy hat, so I was waving at you, becase  I was looking for one... and you were kind  of waving back...And I know the police  already decided it was No Fault, or No Criminality or whatever they call it -- MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. I'm gettin' a little confused over  here. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only nobody said that to them. And I just wanted to like, acknowledge with you that that's what happened. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. First of all, I don't really know what you mean by wavin' at you...What were you, tryin' to catch the bus...? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...Yes. But I wanted to ask about your --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I was wavin' at you like, wavin' to say, you know, "Step away from the bus," if the bus was in motion, I would've waved you away for your-own safety, but that's all that would be.

dialogues.text: You don't remember looking at me and waving at me? Mrs. Maretti comes out again. MARETTI

dialogues.text: No. Not really. No. LISA

dialogues.text: Your brother's on the phone. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'll call him back. Mrs Maretti goes back inside. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to get you in trouble. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're not, because you couldn't get me in trouble. Uhhhh, there's no  criminality found...the report is, uh, final. And that's it. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're just gonna leave it? MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna leave it, because that's all that it was. If something else would have happened, I'd take it to whatever that was. It was tragic, it was a tragedy. But there's only a certain speed the brakes can react. That's a physical limitation of the machine. I don't know what else to tell you. It was a shock. It's shock. But  that's it. Can't bring her back. Cannot bring her back. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about bringing her back. .I'm talking about telling the accident investigators what really happened. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you already talked to them!

dialogues.text: Yellow Revised 10/9/05 - Page 88 112 CONTINUED: (8) 112 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. But I lied. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lied. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And I can understand if you don't want to get in trouble, but.-- MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how come nobody else saw it? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help what other people saw -- MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would think somebody else would see it. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just know what I saw! MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why didn't you say something right then? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because -- when they were asking me what happened -- it seemed like you were kind of looking at me -- like we were saying to each other, "Let's not say anything about what happened." MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now I really don't know what you're talkin' about. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't prove that you were doing that -- Mrs Maretti comes back outside. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I say anything to you? Did I threaten you? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! And I am not blaming you for any of this! All I'm saying is that I didn't really tell the cops what happened, and I  didn't want to go back without -- MARETTI (AFTER "HAPPENED")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you told 'em what you saw! You told 'em what you saw! And so did I! Only I'm the one behind the wheel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revised 10/9/05 - Page 89 112 CONTINUED: (9) 112 MRS MARETTI

You're gonna go back to school and do your homework and I'm gonna lose my job! And  who's gonna feed my kids? You? Are you gonna do it? And for what! She's dead!  She's dead! And there's nothin' I-can do to  bring her back!  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to say what really happened. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey do whatever you fuckin' want. MRS MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry -- ! MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But those cops are gonna laugh in your fuckin' face because this was not my fault!  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was both our fault. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was both our fault. Maretti scrambles in his pocket for a pen. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Don't say that to me.again without a lawyer. Gimme your phone number. MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your number? Gimme LISA your number. Oh, you wanna Mjy? No! Why do you want it? come to my house like some anonymous person, I can't get in touch with you? MRS MARETTI What's your fuckin' number, Gerry! Take it easy! Lisa Cohen! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revised 10/9/05 - Page 89A 112 CONTINUED: (10) 112 MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. (writes) 555 --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revised 10/9/05 - Page 90 112 CONTINUED: (11) 112 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0157. Why do you need it? MARETTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do whatever you're gonna do. I hope you got a good lawyer. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why you're -- Maretti turns and goes in the house. MRS MARETTI

dialogues.text: You know this was very traumatic for him! LISA (FURIOUS)

dialogues.text: It's almost as bad as getting your deg cut OFF MRS MARETTI

dialogues.text: Does your mother know you're here? LISA

dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU on Lisa as she rides back toward Manhattan.

dialogues.text: Emily sits with Lisa at the kitchen table. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you say anything before? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I was afraid. I didn't know what to do.ГўВЂВў EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't know what to do? The woman is killed right in front of you and you didn't know what to do? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it doesn't sound very impressive. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impressive! (Pause) All right: I know you're trying to do the right thing now. What does your mother say? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother hasn't really been that helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 113 CONTINUED: 113 EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean she's got a lot going on right now and she just hasn't been that interested, I guess. EMILY

dialogues.text: What could she possibly have going on? LISA

dialogues.text: Her show is opening. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, her show? What show? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in a play. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend is dead because some guy was looking at your ass and you lied to the police about it, and your mother can't be bothered because she's in a play? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's kind of a big deal for her. She has a really big part. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I don't know your mother, but, that is pretty shocking. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess she's really worried about getting a bad review or something. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. I'm gonna talk to my friend who's a  lawyer, and I'm gonna call Monica's cousin - you talked to her -- And you're gonna go talk to the police. Do you want me'to-go with you? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think maybe you should ask your mother to go with you? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I can handle this part myself.  EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I am so angry. I am so angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 113 CONTINUED: (2) 113 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't do it on purpose. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck him! I'm gonna run over his best  friend and then coerce some teenage girl into lying to the police about it! He had  his chance. Fuck him! Now are you gonna see  this through or not?  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will if you will.  EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK! Thank you. OK?  Emily impulsively and somewhat tearfully embraces Lisa, w is flooded with relief. 113A TIME PERMITTING. 114 INT. THEATER -- BACKSTAGE/ONSTAGE. NIGHT. Joan waits in the wings. Her CUE LIGHT goes ON and OFF. TRACKING her onstage as she enters. JOAN (SHARP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Let me tell you something, Eliot -- She is interrupted by entrance APPLAUSE. JOAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to fire me, go ahead and fire me. Only don't tiptoe around me like.some-kind of deranged ballerina every time I see you in the fucking hall! Now: Do you have  anything to say to me, Eliot? VICTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um -- you're not fired...? This gets a pretty big laugh from the audience. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (Abashed, friendly) What are you guys talking about? Another big laugh. IN THE AUDIENCE -- LISA, CURTIS and RAMON sit together, dressed up for opening night. Ramon nudges Lisa.  RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's good, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93 114 CONTINUED: 114 LISA

dialogues.text: (Grudging but proud)  Yes...

dialogues.text: Lisa is on the computer. Joan is standing behind her.  JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find it? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute!  JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we just forget it? If they were any  good somebody would have called me last  night.  LISA

dialogues.text: No we can't forget it, because I can't take  this anymore. What do you care what they  say about you anyway? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't. It's just a lousy feeling. Can't  you understand that? If they wrote mean things about you in the newspaper you wouldn't like it. Even if you didn't agree with it, or base your self-esteem on it. Why can't you understand that? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do understand it, because we have this conversation every time! You're great in the play, you're a great actress, everybody thinks you're great, everything about you  is great, you're really really pretty --  JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shut up.  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let me just find the review and then we can both kill ourselves, OK? JOAN

dialogues.text: Fine.  Lisa finds The New York Times review online.  LISA OK: JOAN

dialogues.text: Did you find it?

dialogues.text: Green Revised 10/7/05 - Page 94 115 CONTINUED: 115 LISA

dialogues.text: Yes. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it bad? LISA

dialogues.text: It is? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Listen to this: JOAN

dialogues.text: Don't read it to me. LISA

dialogues.text: ".. .but it is the frankly extraordinary Joan Kaplan who transforms the savage wit of David Holmes' acid comedy-drama into something approaching sheer luminosity..." JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "But don't be misled by her feather-light touch and expert comic timing. With the canny (Has trouble enunciating:) bray... JOAN

dialogues.text: Bravura? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. "-- of an actor at the JOAN Top of Craft, Ms. Kaplan takes Top of Craft...? us on an emotional roller coaster that is both hilarious and heartbreaking, maddening and magical." JOAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. This is the best review I've ever read. JOAN

dialogues.text: Just for me, or for everyone?

No, old Palestinian was stopped I never read them unless by Israeli police from boarding I know there's nothing a-school bus yesterday carrying mean in them ... Victor, forty pounds of explosive under I wish you wouldn't her jacket -- speak to me that way: You know I'm Top of Craft. Lisa closes the door or turns up the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is reading from a paperback poetry anthology. On the blackboard it says "19TH CENTURY POETS -- GERARD MANLEY HOPKINS -- 1844-1889." SLOW PUSH IN on Lisa. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spring and Fall to a young girl by Gerard Manley Hopkins.  "Margaret are you grieving Over Goldengrove unleaving? Leaves, like the things of man, you With your fresh thoughts care for, can you? Ahl as the heart grows older It will come to such thoughts colder (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By and by, nor spare a sigh Though worlds of wanwood leafmeal lie, (MORE)
