dialogues.text: 96 116 CONTINUED: (2) 116 JOHN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet you will weep, and know why. Now no matter, child, the name: Sorrow springs are the same. Nor mouth had, no nor mind, expressed What heart heard of, ghost guessed: It is the blight man was born for, It is Margaret you mourn for." Silence. JOHN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any thoughts? Lisa? Lisa looks up slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa gets out a taxi in front of the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa walks up to the desk of a 2ND A.I.S.DETECTIVE.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Could I help you? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, yeah. Is Detective Mitchell here?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: No he's not. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Um -- I talked to him on Monday and he said he'd be here after three...

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's not back yet. Could I help you with something? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, well, do you know when do you expect him?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: What's this about? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was involved in an accident a few weeks AGO --

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Uh huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 119 CONTINUED: 119 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I filled out a report with Detective Mitchell, but wanted to amend the report, so I thought I should --

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: What do you mean amend the report? How do you want to amend it? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there was something I didn't tell him, and I wanted to tell him, because --

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: So wait, I don't understand. You wanna change your statement? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes! I want to change my statement. (Pause. Calmer) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Well, you'd usually have to talk to the  investigating detective on the case... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I know. That's why I asked to see  Detective Mitchell. Who said he'd be here  now. Which he's not. So...

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: (ON "SO")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember the case number?  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Sorry. It was that woman Monica Patterson, who got run over by the bus, on Broadway -- it was in a lot of the newspapers...

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: OK, yeah, sure OK. Sit down, sit down.  LISA (SITTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I ---

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: You know the case is closed. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume it was. But part of the reason  it's closed is because of my statement. And the statement I gave --

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Because of your statement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 119 CONTINUED: (2) 119

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another male detective walks by, behind LISA. The two men exchange a glance referring to Lisa being a cute girl. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: What do you mean it was closed because of your statement? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean --

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: The DA's office closes the case. You don't close the case. The DA's office closes the case. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it does. I obviously didn't mean I personally closed the case, like, legally. I meant that what I said was probably instrumental in getting the case closed, because I was the --

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: What's your name, honey? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa Cohen.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: OK -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me honey, OK? Pause.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you not gonna help me now that I said that?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Look -- what's your name? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa Cohen!

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: OK Lisa, first thing, you're gonna calm DOWN --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 99 119 CONTINUED: (3) 119 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calm right now!

dialogues.speaker: 2ND A.I.S. DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: OK. Just checking. Second thing -- Oh! Here he is: Your knight in shining armor. MITCHELL has just come in. LISA gets up. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy been givin' you a hard time? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this guy been sayin' to you? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I don't know if you remember me... I'm Lisa Cohen. I called you on  Monday? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I do. What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa sits across from Mitchell. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now you're sayin' he ran the light.  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He wasn't even looking at the road. And I was definitely trying to get his attention... MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I get the picture. So you're flirtin' with this guy, he's wavin' at you, he runs the light, hits the decedent, she dies on the scene...the both of youse lie to me on both of your statements, and then somewheres in there you turn around, decide the guy belongs in jail. That right? That about right? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any control over if he goes to jail or not. I certainly have my hopes. I just want to set the record straight, so that if he gets away with this I won't have been a part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 120 CONTINUED: 120 MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you think I should do with you? Just gimmeГўВЂВўa clue. 'cause I'm just a little bit lost over here...: LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do whatever you want. I know what I did.  MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Well. Before we do anything, Lisa, anybody will tell you that just because he ran a red light is not a criminal offence.  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if he kills someone? MITCHELL (SIMULTANEOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if you cause an accidental death,  that's right. For this to be a criminal offense, the law says you need two  aggravating circumstances. Like he ran a red light and he was speeding. Or he ran a red light and he was -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On 2nd "red") So he's not liable to be prosecuted for manslaughter? Or second degree murder? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He could be charged with reckless driving, and fillip' out a false police report. Which, that's no joke -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's unbelievable! What does he have to do? Kill her on purpose? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Because that's the definition of murder. Killin' somebody on purpose. You're not sayin' he ran her over on purpose, are you? Pause. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Pause. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All, right, look. Lemme take another statement, and, uh...We'11 look into it,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 120 CONTINUED: (2) 120 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'll go over it with my sergeant, probably pull this guy in again. Reinterview him. Put a little pressure on him. See what he says. LISA (VERY GRATEFUL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...! Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa and her coed class watch BONNIE, the young, tall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: beautiful, no-makeup gymnastics teacher. BONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, so we're just gonna start with a_couple  of simple stretches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stretches. Lisa notices the boys looking at Bonnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa and Becky are smoking pot on a rock or bench. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding in smoke) .Yeah, because the Central Park Conservatory or whatever it's called put up about five hundred miles worth of these  cheap shitty-looking fences all over the park. Which is totally antithetical to what the park was originally designed for. She exhales and hands Becky the joint. BECKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are totally gonna miss the game. Oh my God it's John...! It's John! They try to hide the joint from JOHN, the English teacher who approaches them and stops. Pause. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi John. BECKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi John. (Pause) Want some? They giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 121 CONTINUED: 121 JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, guys. You can't be smokin' a j. on your way to a school soccer game! Now come on! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. BECKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're really sorry. John glares at them, then turns and walks away. LISA (STAGE WHISPER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK: How about how he's like, "Smokin' a j." Like, "You can't be smokin' a j." They all burst out laughing.  CU on the angry embarrassed back of John's reddening grow neck as he keeps walking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa walks through the park, somewhat stoned, enjoying th sunshine. She sees MR AARON approaching on a bike. He bik up to her and stops. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mr Aaron...! MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Lisa? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pretty damn good. How are you? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right, I'm all right-Tell me something. Whatever happened with that situation? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...ГўВЂВўI'm working on it. I'll tell you all about it sometime...(squinting at him in the sunshine) Hey, what kind of a bike is that? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, a Trek. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to take a horseback riding trip with my father over Christmas break and I was just wondering, does it bear any resemblance to riding a bicycle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 122 CONTINUED: 122 MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as I know, no, it doesn't, no... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you must have ridden a lot of horses. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you say so? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you from Texas or Wyoming or someplace like that? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someplace like what? - LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know: Not New York. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm actually from Indiana. But don't let me overwhelm you with superfluous details.  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, so what are you doing at a New York private school teaching geometry to a bunch of overprivileged liberal Jews? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a real question, or a Lisa  question? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a Lisa question? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A question designed to prolong the conversation without there being any particular interest in the actual answer...? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About half and half.  MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case --  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you go, I am actually thinking of getting one of these. Can I try it? Just  for one second? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104 122 CONTINUED: (2) 122

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron gets off the bike. She climbs on. The seat is too h for her. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to adjust the seat? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. This actually feels really, really good. God, I'm kidding! You are so  easy to tease! She bikes away awkwardly, turns around and bikes back tow him, wobbling badly. LISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your bicycle...! Can I have it? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! She tries to stop in front of him but skids and he catche her hard by the arms to stop her.

dialogues.speaker: MR AARON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK. Off. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I just ask you how is it possible that I am totally in love with you and you have almost no interest in me whatsoever? It's not like I'd ever say anything if you ever deigned to like, you know, be with me. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa...! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you like me. It's not like I'm a  virgin, if that's what you're worried about. I'm not even close.  MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't even be having this conversation with you. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you keep saying that, but I notice you're still standing here. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right. Goodbye. He gets on the bike. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my fault if I revere you as a god!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 105 122 CONTINUED: (3) 122

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs or smiles briefly in spite of himself. LISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. I made you laugh. I am so happy right now. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you in class. We pull away with him as she watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa walks in as Joan is putting on her coat. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Where have you been? I didn't know.if you wanted dinner. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- no thanks. I'll order something. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone named Emily called. And Detective Mitchell called from the Accident Investigation Squad. Is that the one you talked to? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, did he say anything? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to call him back. What's going on? Did  you ever go back and see him?  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather not talk about it when you have one foot out the door. I'll tell you later, if that's OK. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is. Who's Emily? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the friend of the woman who died, the one who had the funeral... JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, OK. Well, her number's by the  phone. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. How's Ramon? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God. I don't know. I mean I really like him. He's really nice. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revised 10/7/05 - Page 106 123 CONTINUED: 123 JOAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not sure he actually ever understands a word I say. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him a chance, Mom, you just met-the guy. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't you know what I mean? I just feel kind of lonely when I'm with him. You know? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel lonely when you're with him? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You never felt that way when you were with someone? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so. I feel that way all the time. You get used to it. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ...I don't know how serious I want to get with somebody who makes me feel that way. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So don't get serious. That's my advice. Pause. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'm gonna go. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good show. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (calling) Goodbye Curtis!

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM. SIMULTANEOUS 124
dialogues.text: Curtis, busy with his computer, doesn't answer. BACK IN THE FRONT HALL -- Joan shrugs it off. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hits the elevator button. Sees her reflection in the little round elevator window. She looks old to herself, a haggard. She touches under her chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan gets in. The door shuts. She leans her head against wall and bursts into tears., The elevator stops with a DI She wipes her eyes quickly. A woman NEIGHBOR comes in. NEIGHBOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...! JOAN (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. NEIGHBOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations on the show...! JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. NEIGHBOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was such a wonderful review...! And I read somewhere it might be going to Broadway? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supposedly. In March. NEIGHBOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God! Exciting...! JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's going well. Knock wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, Emily and DAVE, a good natured intelligent 35ish lawyer, are at a window table. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, Dave is one of my best friends. He's a terrific lawyer and if he doesn't know what to do himself he'll certainly know someone we can talk to. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, great. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Dave, just tell Lisa everything you told me, if you don't mind repeating YOURSELF -- DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. I love to repeat myself. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you guys gonna order something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are drinking coffee. Lisa smokes. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When someone is killed it's what you call a Wrongful Death Suit, which is a statutory case, which just means there's a statute passed by the legislature which gives you the right to bring the case. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As opposed to what? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As opposed to common law, which is law made by judges. Which is why the damages are limited. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, just skip that part. We don't care about that. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we were trying to get the police to arrest this guy...! DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- the police are not, uh --  LISA EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? They told me they Dave doesn't think the  were gonna look into it police are gonna --  again. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just telling you that even if they do, there is no way in this world they are gonna recommend to the DA that they charge this guy. That's why -- LISA (ON "THAT'S")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what can we do? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. I'm -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revised 9/25/05 - Page 109 128 CONTINUED: 128 DAVE EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK -- That's OK, honey... DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just getting to that. You can't do anything unless you're a relative -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't have any relatives, except for  those idiots in Arizona -- DAVE (ON "EXCEPT")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- or -- hang on a minute -- unless you're executor of her estate -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the executor of her estate. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which is Emily. I know. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So good. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. This is good. Because the executor of the estate Cdn bring a Wrongful Death suit, but the beneficiary has to be a relative. So let me explain about that. In a Wrongful Death suit you can sue for Pain and Suffering, Pecuniary Losses, Lose of Support or Services.. .And also what's called Care, Comfort and Society: --like advice, counseling of the parent that the kids aren't gonna get anymore... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can really sue for that? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and that's probably what we would do, LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So -- I don't understand. Who are we suing? The bus driver? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, because the bus driver wouldn't have any money. You basically sue everybody and hope something sticks. The person who pays will be the MTA's insurance company. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But do you think the driver would get fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revised 9/25/05 - Page 109A 128 CONTINUED: (2) 128 DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not necessarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 128 CONTINUED: (3) 128 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if all the facts came out at the trial? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. I don't know. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how much could they be liable for? DAVE EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends: How badly do you think we could ever hurt them? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- if she was alive, in great pain for an  extended period of time, they give more money for that. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say she was alive for ten minutes. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I gather in a lot .of pain? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her leg was cut off. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- obviously. And -- but was she conscious? Awake, the whole time? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Emily. (To DAVE) Yeah, awake. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if she was in a lot of pain for that long ...I don't know. . .maybe 300,000 or a half a million dollars to get a sustainable verdict? A brain damaged baby would beГўВЂВў  three million. But the truth is, Lisa,  after all's said and done, it's not a very good case. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's your word against his, and because you already lied on your first deposition. A red light case is a fifty- fifty proposition already. And with only one eyewitness, with two conflicting statements? I wouldn't take-that case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revised 9/25/05 - Page 111 128 CONTINUED: (4) 128 EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody really cares about getting a lot of money here. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand that -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just want this prick to Buffer. and we want the bus company to take resonsibility for hiring this guy. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. But no matter how you slice it, the fact that Lisa lied on her first statement is a disaster for your lawyer. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't I explain why I lied the first time? It's not like I'm trying to get any money for myself. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true-Since she have no financial interest she can't be impeached for bias. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impeached for what? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't have her credibility attacked on financial grounds because the jury knows you're not getting any money if you win. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's'something, isn't it? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But do you really think we know what that means? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. That's what its called. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who are you talking to? You know we don't know what that means. It's like you're not really concentrating. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- don't know. I am concentrating. I'm just thinking out loud. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OX. All right. I'm sorry...I (TO LISA)  (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revised 9/25/05 - Page 111A 128 CONTINUED: ( 5) 128 EMILY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't always a lawyer you know. He used to be a very nice little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revised 9/25/05 - Page 112 128 CONTINUED: ( 6) 129 DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway.. the only thing I could think of is it i@ the MTA. So they're not gonna want a lot of publicity. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, the whole point is to get this guy -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is to fucking get this guyl LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, its to get him out from behind the wheel of a bus! DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she know she was dying? I only ask because the terror of knowing you're dying raises the damages. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she had a pretty good idea. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she had lived for a couple of days it would make the case better...I know this sounds horrible, but this is what it comes down to... EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. We know, Dave. That's OK. Silence. Emily starts to speak: DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I actually did have one more thought...I do know one guy who's, uh... You know what? Yo know what I want to do7 I want to make a few phone calls, and then, just let me get back to you. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would just like somebody to take responsibility for what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa is on the kitchen phone. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Detective Mitchell please? . My name is Lisa Cohen? C 0 H -- Yes, I'll hold. (On hold) Fuck you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revised 9/25/05 - Page 112A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell picks up the phone. WE CUT BETWEEN THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113 130 CONTINUED: 130 MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Mitchell. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, it's Lisa Cohen calling. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Lisa, what can I do for you? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was just wondering what ever happened, if anything, with the case. You said you might re-interview the bus driver... MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we did:.We brought him back in -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did? What happened? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he basically stuck to his original representation, and that was pretty much it. I brought it up with my sergeant, but he agrees with me we still don't have enough to charge this guy, so there's really not a lot more we can do at this point. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how did you ask the questions? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's obviously not gonna change his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: statement if you just ask him like really politely: Why would he? We already know he's a liar. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you know, Lisa, in the old days we'd just throw him in the back with a rubber hose and we'd get whatever answer we want out of him. But fortunately we don't do  that kind of thing anymore -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, not to white people. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 114 130 CONTINUED: (2) 130 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't do it to white people. Anyway,  I'm not saying you --  MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't do it to who? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God... MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, I don't know why you're bringin' the guy's race into it. There's forty thousand cops in this city -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you, yes. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and I hate to disillusion you, but most of 'em are pretty good guys, just tryin' to do their job. Bottom line is the DA's not gonna take this case. (Pause) Now you could talk to my sergeant if you want to, but -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, dressed to go to work, drops her keys in her purse she comes down the hall and lingers in the kitchen doorwa find LISA on the phone, listening, then: LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there's no way to appeal --

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT V.O.
dialogues.text: (over the phone, flat) There's nothin' to appeal. There's no case. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how do you know Detective Mitchell interrogated him aggressively enough if you weren't there? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? LISA waves her away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Ramon are having drinks and looking at his great view of the Upper West Side. Joan is smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 115 132 CONTINUED: 132 JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- so funny: it's the same show, but now they all read how great it is, we get these big standing ovations every night, and it's the exact same show as before. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why do you put yourself down? It's a wonderful show and a wonderful performance. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not -- I'm not putting myself down. It's just that the audience always reacts differently if they've been told it's good. A lot of actors have that experience. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm hm? She takes a few steps away. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love this view...(Pause) You know, Ramon...this may sound very stupid to you, but do you ever worry that we don't have very much in common? RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't mean to sound dissatisfied, or disgruntled. But I feel like we're  always misunderstanding each other. Do you feel that way at all? Or am I just completely off the beam? RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we should talk about that, Joan. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't? Well...I think it's kind of  important or I wouldn't have brought it up.  RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan... I like you very much. But let's not talk about what you are like, and what I am like. That never makes a good result. Talk  about it with your friends. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends...! RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Pink Revised 11/17/05 - Page 116 132 CONTINUED: (2) 132

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sips his drink. Joan doesn't know what to say. Pause. RAMON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I show you some pictures of my boys? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Just don't tell me what they're like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon and Joan are in his modernistic, scrupulously clean carpeted living room, on the sofa, looking at pictures. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a little place we used to go on holiday, two hours outside of Cartagena...My family is all there still, but Rodrigo is studying in London, and Hector is in Geneva. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh...  RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they will go back eventually, because they like to do something for their  country. But it's a worry, because it's  very bad there now. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...I haven't really been following it. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a big, big mess. Last year I helped to found an organization to work with children whose families have been killed, or the parents have been kidnapped, so they don't know if they are alive or dead. We try to find homes for them, preferably in Colombia, because if we lose our young people, that's it: That's the future. We have raised a lot of money, but there's only so much we can do. You don't like to say it's hopeless, but it's hard to see the solution. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. God...I wish I knew more about it...Do you mind if I ask you something? RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you interested in me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Pink Revised 11/17/05 - Page 116A

dialogues.speaker: 132A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I should be? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel kind of ignorant about your whole world... RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it would be better if we knew about all the same things? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really, not exclusively. It's just unusual. Don't you think it's unusual?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Pink Revised 11/17/05 - Page 117

dialogues.speaker: 132A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you travel a lot. I've only been out of the country a few times in my whole life. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should travel more. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I've always wanted to. It's hard when you're in the theater... RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, you should try. It's a big world. You're an artist. You should see more of it. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. You don't have to keep saying that. I've always wanted to travel. It's just a little difficult with two kids and no husband, but it's hard to make a lot of money in the theater. I was on a TV show a few years back and I socked away some money because of that, but my ex-husband -- RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl, yes, you remembered, very good. Karl's very generous with the kids when he can be, but he's struggling too: He's a director: he directs commercials, and now he's trying to produce them... Anyway, I'm not ignorant because I enjoy it. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't say you're ignorant... Do you think Lisa will be interested in acting?  JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. I think's she's got a lot of contempt for it. Of course that may be the age. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She would prefer the world with no plays?  No films? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Who knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Pink Revised 11/17/05 - Page 117A

dialogues.speaker: 132A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to see a picture of my mother? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are all my aunts and uncles...See? Big family... JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. She looks at him as he turns the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa and Emily meet in front of Dave's office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks Lisa and Emily into his office. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So after I talked to you guys I called this P.I. I know and I asked him to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revised 9/25/05 - Page 118 134 CONTINUED: 134 EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called a what? A what? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private Investigator -- to see if he could find anything out about your bus driver -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? DAVE EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah: So he -- Dave! DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, let me tell you what he said! So he called this guy he knows who used to be a cop for the MTA. Did you know the MTA have their own police? The MTA police? They have their own uniforms... EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Yeah? Yeah? DAVE EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And -- Just a minutel Jesus Christ! What do we give a fuck about the MTA  police and their uniforms?!  DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- so this guy got someone to let him sneak a look at your guy's file. And it turns out he's had two previous accidents -- less than two years apart -- one of them on the job, one in his own car -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where there was some allegation that he was drinking, which was dropped, but, that  he's never been cited or disciplined, just moved around to different shifts -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does this not shock me? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because Surprise Surprise his brother-in- law is a very big muckety-muck in the Transit Workers Union --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revised 9/25/05 - Page 119 134 CONTINUED: (2) 134 EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (i.e., "I get it.") O-Kay...l DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you read the paper, you'll know they're going through a protracted labor dispute at the MTA right now, and according to my PI, the management doesn't want to aggravate the situation by firing this guy. Especially since the police have concluded he was not at fault. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is making me sick. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but what it means, Lisa, is that we have a case. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What it means, in fact, is that we have a very good case, because we can sue for what's called "Negligent Retention." Which means they should have known the guy was a bad risk and was irresponsible and they negligently retained him until he finally killed somebody. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can prove that? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, because we can subpoena their Personnel records, which we already know contain damaging information, because my investigator got a look at them beforehand. Which you're not-supposed to do, but we did it anyway. LISA YOU'RE AWESOMEL EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that means... DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means we're in great shape and I think we should go in there and sue their fuckin' asses off. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you wouldn't be our lawyer, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revised 9/25/05 - Page 120 134 CONTINUED: (3) 134 DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no. Oh no. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? DAVE EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a personal injury It's not his area. litigator. I don't know enough about it. I would lose. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you could recommend someone? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I know a guy who's very good. His name is Russel Deutsch. He's not a sleazebag. Very experienced. Let me give you his number... EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, thank you so much. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. My God. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you gotta get that crazy cousin on board because she's gonna be your beneficiary. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not gonna want to come to New York, I can tell you that right now. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you win she gets anywhere from three to five hundred thousand dollars. She's gonna come to New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa and Emily walk up the busy avenue. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with Monica and her cousin? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Monica's father left some money to Abigail's kids and he made Monica the executor of the estate, because he didn't want Abigail and her idiot husband to get their hands on the money before the kids were grown up. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revised 10/7/05 - Page 121 135 CONTINUED: 135 EMILY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For which Abigail rewarded her by badgering her about it on the phone for fifteen years: Always trying to borrow money against the estate, accusing her of making lousy investments with it, nasty phone calls, nasty letters, every month for fifteen years until Abigail's daughter turned twenty-one and got married. Then Monica goes to the wedding, in fucking Arizona, and Abigail literally won't speak to her. She's a dream. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's who we're getting the money for? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not who we're getting it for, it's who we're getting it from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and Lisa sit with RUSSEL DEUTSCH, 50s. His law offi is slightly smaller and less nice than Dave's. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First thing we do is we file a summons and a complaint against the MTA. They get .twenty days to respond, and when they do we can make our Discovery requests: Accident reports, personnel records, et cetera. But you gotta realize it's gonna take some time. The law says you have to get a court date within a year. Usually it takes about six. Depending. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six years! DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depending, yes. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I mentioned to Dave I have a friend who writes for the Metro section of the Times... DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes: Now this, if it could really happen, this changes everything in our favor. If they think there's gonna be adverse publicity, especially in The New York Times, they're gonna want to settle right away, soon as possible, and as quietly as POSSIBLE -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they'd.make it a condition that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 136 CONTINUED: 136 DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's usually done, you get the money but you can't talk about it. Nobody knows the terms. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what good does that do? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get the money. (Pause) is that bad? (Pause) I thought that's what we're all  here for. (Pause) This is how our society  punishes people for doing bad things. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By getting money from their employers' insurance. companies? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's called Punitive Damages. Pause. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we insist they fire the driver? As part of the settlement? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sure, why not?  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But is that something people do? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. It's one of your conditions. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you think we're gonna win? They're gonna settle? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh they're gonna settle. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is -- Emily and Lisa take hands and squeeze. 137 INT. COHEN APARTMENT -- LIVING ROOM. LATER THAT DAY. JOAN is reading LISA's C average REPORT CARD and an  accompanying letter. Lisa comes in and stops short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 123 137 CONTINUED: 137 JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you.  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd I do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily opens the front door for Joan and Lisa. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Joan. It's nice to meet you. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you too. Come on in. - LISA (SARDONICALLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, Joan and Lisa settle on the sofa and chairs. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .I had a friend who used to live on this block, at 262...? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don't know if you know her. Cheryl Rowan? She's a physiotherapist? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't know her. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think about a thousand people must...  JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing... EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa says you're in a play, Joan? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Yeah... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should go see it, it's really good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 124 139 CONTINUED: 139 JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the play is great, and it's a really nice cast..-. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just being modest. She's gonna win every award in New York. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- all that stuff's a long way off. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't go to the theater very much. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's just nice, because you can work a long time in the theater and play really good parts without getting a lot of recognition. And even though you don't  necessarily do it for that as your primary motive, it is very nice when people do notice something you've done. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh... JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on a television show a few years ago, and I had been doing theater all my life, and suddenly all my relatives started calling me up to congratulate me because they thought I finally Made It. And it was really just this dumb show that paid the bills for a while... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That show was so stupid. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't that bad...! Anyway: I realize this is horribly embarrassing for Lisa, but I really wanted to meet you, Emily, because you've frankly become such a big part of Lisa's life, and I don't want to be intrusive, but this whole court case seems to be suddenly dominating everything and I can't get Lisa to tell me anything about it LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true...! JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't...! And I want you to know, Lisa, that I'm very, very proud of you for pursuing this the way you have. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 125 139 CONTINUED: (2) 139 JOAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't let you pursue it to the point where it's taking over your life or interfering with your school work. (To EMILY) It's really come down to a question of homework. Lisa is on a half-scholarship at her school. And I know she feels a real  sense of responsibility about what happened LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you do. I know you do. But you can't not do your homework, and you can't throw away your scholarship because of it. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. My grades slipped a little. They'll get better. Anyone can do their homework. You just sit down and do it. I've been distracted. I'll stop. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't need to have a big conference about it. JOAN (EMBARRASSED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a big conference, I just want to know what's going on. And I wanted to meet Emily... (to EMILY) I know it's a little awkward! EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't apologize. If Lisa hasn't been keeping you apprised of what's been going on, I think she should. You should. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to keep her apprised of., We're just waiting for them to schedule the Discovery conference. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what is that? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom? It really doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 126 139 CONTINUED: (3) 139 EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Discovery conference is a meeting with the court where they sign an order. authorizing our lawyer to begin getting the personnel records, interviewing witnesses, talking to Monica's cousin... JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, now where does she fit in? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABIGAIL BERWITZ, 40s, gets out the taxi as the driver com around with her matching luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abigail sits with Deutsch. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you describe the relationship overall? Did you talk on the phone a lot? Were there a lot of visits -- ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would say we talked on the phone a couple of times a month at least. Sometimes more than that...I would call her, she would call me... DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what were the nature of these conversations? ABIGAIL. Oh, family stuff, mostly. Her family, my kids... DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she would advise you about your family? That kind of thing? ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I would say so, yes. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you have any phone records? Or -- ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have all my phone bills, if that's what you mean. I didn't record the actual conversations...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 127 141 CONTINUED: 141 DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no -- ABIGAIL (PRODUCES BILLS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see we talked on the phone quite frequently. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, that's terrific. I see you came prepared...1 ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I wanted to bring everything. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now when they take your deposition you're gonna say the same thing you just told me. Talk about the relationship... ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of advice she used to give you... ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, Lisa and Abigail sit over their lunch. Abigail is drinking a white wine.  ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Emily, where did you find this lawyer? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was recommended by a friend. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking because my husband knows a real good New York lawyer, and I'm not entirely comfortable with someone that no one has ever heard of -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend's heard of him. He says he's very good.. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he does. But I have a  responsibility in this situation, and I would feel a whole lot more comfortable with somebody who didn't just drop in out of the clear blue sky...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revised 11/20/05 - Page 128 142 CONTINUED: 142 EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't drop in out of the clear blue sky. He was recommended by my friend. But even if we switched lawyers we'd still have to pay him. But it all comes out of the settlement, so it's really up to you. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, if you all think he's good... EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know whether he is or not. My friend thinks he is. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Now Lisa, what is your involvement in all this? What's your angle? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to...I was just there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily comes into the dining room with a cup of coffee. Li is standing over the table looking at some of Monica's ph and belongings which are spread out all over the table. E starts putting the pictures away in their envelopes. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, is that you? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's you and Monica obviously. Oh my

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God. Is that her daughter? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God... So how old was she when she died?  EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God. I can't even imagine.  EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither could we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily sits down and starts sorting through pictures to pu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: them in the box. Lisa sits down too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revised 11/20/05 - Page 128aA 143 CONTINUED: 143 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Monica asked about her when she was dying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revised 11/20/05 - Page 128A-129 143 CONTINUED: (2) 143

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily looks up. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I didn't. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think she was confused... like, I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: think she thought I was her daughter for a minute. And then she was asking me to call her, like to tell her what happened: You know, like she didn't remember she was dead. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? What did she say? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just asked if somebody could call her daughter. But then it got confusing because I said, "Sure, what's her name?" And she said her name was Lisa. And I said, "No, that's my name." Because it took me a minute -- I didn't realize we had the same name... Emily does not respond. LISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I couldn't tell if what I was saying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: was registering with her. Emily does not respond. LISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then when I found out her daughter was dead, ever since then I keep having this really strong feeling that some way, for those last five minutes I kind of was her daughter. You know? Like maybe that's the reason I was there: Like in some weird way, this obviously amazing woman got to see her daughter again for a few minutes, right before she died. EMILY (VERY DRY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. And is she still inhabiting your body? Or did she go right back to the spirit world after it was over? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean she ws literally inhabiting my body. I don't believe in all that stuff at all.  EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a fuck what you believe in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revised 11/20/05 - Page 129aA 143 CONTINUED: ( 3) 143 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Why are you so mad at me!?  EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because this is not an opera! LISA (FLUSHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You think I think this is an opera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revised 11/20/05 - Page 129A-130 143 CONTINUED: ( 4) 143 EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm making this into a dramatic situation because I think it's dramatic?!? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're very young. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that have to do with anything? If anything I think it means I care more than someone who's older! Because this kind of thing has never happened to me before! EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it means you care more easily! There's a big difference! Except that it's not you it's happening to! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is! I know I'm not the one who was run over -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, you weren't. And you're not the one who died of leukemia, and you're not the one who just died in an earthquake in -- Algeria! But you will be. Do you understand me? You will be. And it's not an opera and it's not dramatic -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm well aware of that! EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this first-blush phony deepness of yours is worth nothing. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh wow. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand? It's not worth anything, because it'll be troweled over in a month or two. And then when you get older, and you don't have a big reaction every time a d gets run over, then, then we'll find out what kind of a person you are! But this is nothing! I'm sorry, but I didn't start this conversation and I don't play these games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revised 11/20/05 - Page 131 143 CONTINUED: ( 5) 143 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drawing herself up) I am not -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't look so outraged! Because I'm not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: saying anything very outrageous! I'm telling you to knock it off! You have every right to falsify your own life, but you have no right to falsify anyone else's. It's what makes people into Nazis! And I'm sorry, but it's a little suspicious that you're making such a fuss about this when you didn't know her, and you're having troubles with your own mother -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is nm life we're talking about, much more than it is yours! Because it's my real friend who got killed, who I'm never going to see again, really! Whom I have known since I was nineteen years old myself. OK? And I don't want that sucked into some kind of adolescent self- dramatization! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not fucking dramatizing anything! EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not having it) OK -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was there, and you weren't! And if I happen to express myself a little hyperbolically, Emily, that's just the way I talk! I can't help it if my mother is an actress! Why are you being so fucking strident? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strident? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Um, you should leave. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Because I called you strident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 132 143 CONTINUED: ( 6) 143 EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah: Strident? You should leave. Thanks. I don't wanna be called strident and you're deliberately misunderstanding me! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not! You're insulting me enough as it is: You don't have to call me stupid too! EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I can't stop you doing this so I think you had better go. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK! I will. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: NOW
dialogues.text: LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK! Let me get my purse! Lisa grabs her purse and coat. Emily half-walks, half-dri her toward the door. LISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this mean we're dropping the whole inquiry? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means you're leaving. I don't know what else it means. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I meant by saying you were strident was that you were being emphatic! I obviously misused the word! EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look it up when you get home. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. You're amazing. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Uh huh. I'm amazing. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bursts into tears) Why are you doing this... .! EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, I'm not doing anything! I'm a human being! Monica was a human being! So was her daughter! And so is your mother! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revised 11/20/05 - Page 133 143 CONTINUED: ( 7) 143

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: We are not supporting characters in the fascinating story of your life! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said or thought you were...! And I really didn't mean to call you strident! I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: totally misused the word! I wasn't trying to insult you, Emily, I really wasn't! I feel so bad about what happened and I'm trying so hard to do something about it! And I don't understand why if I say something wrong you can't just give me a break! I didn't mean I thought her daughter took over my body. I'm not an idiot. It was just this feeling I had because she was holding onto my hand so hard before she died, and because we had the same first name! EMILY

dialogues.speaker: OK...
dialogues.text: LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not trying to dramatize anything,  Emily. I really know about that trend, and  I really don't think I've been doing that.  EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. I believe you. And look up "strident."  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. They kiss and make up, but it's still a little ugly.

dialogues.text: No. CURTIS

Because start -- Oh, it's not because they both like to kill they've been occupied and Jews. humiliated and bombed out of their homes for the last KLEIN fifty years? Hey! Hey! Lisa! Hey! LEWIS LISA
