dialogues.text: 140 147 CONTINUED: 147 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and I guess I lost my cool a little, but I just love it'when people start comparing the Israelis to Nazis... JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who is running these discussions...? RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, but Lisa, you have to remember, it's always easy for the dominant side to be content with the status quo. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. - EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you mean, Ramon? RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the oppressor is always in favor of law and order because it's his law and his order. He uses violence to maintain his  position and calls it the rule of law. But  when the person underfoot uses violence to change his status he's called a criminal and a terrorist, and the violence of the State is called upon to put him down, and  once again it's called the rule of law. In COLOMBIA -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. And what would you like them to do? Pause. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "They" meaning -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jew oppressors. What would you like them to do? Pause. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't use that expression. EMILY But since you ask - No, you didn't. (i.e. "You didn't have to.") LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I just spent the whole day arguing about this: I didn't really mean to bring it up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 141 147 CONTINUED: (2) 147 EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning on her) Don't handle me. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not handling you. JOAN (GENERALLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think of the play? RAMON LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I think it's ironic in Don't bother, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the extreme that the victims of Nazis find it essential EMILY -- find it essential to If the Israelis were like use the Nazi tactics to Nazis there wouldn't be sustain their occupation. any Arabs left, and I'm leaving. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agreeing with Emily) That's what I think! Emily tries to unhook her purse from the back of her chai JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That seems excessive, Emily, come on -- RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the response. That's the Jewish response. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the what? RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Jewish response. You don't like what I am saying or what I do, so you -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my Jewish response. Emily throws her drink in his face and walks away. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God...! RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right...(Wiping off his face) That's all right... It's a perfect little .encapsule...It's the Jewish response. A horrible silence as they watch Ramon clean his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan is getting ready-for bed. Lisa appears in the doorwa LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about all that tonight. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Your friend is a delight. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a really passionate person. She really cares about things. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's rude, Lisa. Ramon was my guest, not hers. And-so.was she, as a matter of fact -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? Why is it so JOAN important that people be No -- I'm not ar -- I'm polite all the time? Why not arguing about this with is that the big priority? you! I'm not interested in an exchange of ideas. As it happens Ramon said a few things I wasn't too crazy about either, so I guess that's the end of that... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh is that supposed to be Emily's fault too? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk to you right now. Please go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon is on the phone in his big midtown corner office. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Joan, I won't defend myself. All what I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: meant was, that was the typical response you will get from someone who will take that position that that woman was taking.  But if you like to break up with me because  I used the wrong adjective, what I'm going  to do? I'm not going to beg you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan enters slowly and checks the water on the stove. Lis is eating a carrot and reading a magazine. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 143 150 CONTINUED: 150 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...? How's that anti-Semitic piece of shit Ramon?- JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, I don't know. The PHONE RINGS. Lisa picks up. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? KARL (ON PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's Dad.

dialogues.speaker: WE CUT BETWEEN THEM.
dialogues.text: LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad, how are you? I'm really looking forward to our horseback riding trip... KARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's why I'm calling. I don't think it's going to happen. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? What's the matter? KARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's the matter. Nobody seems to really want to go, and I don't really feel like spending three thousand bucks on something nobody has the slightest interest in. So I think it's obviously better for everyone if we just cancel. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said I didn't want to go. KARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't seem to get a straight answer about what anybody wants to eat, um, Annette is giving me a hard time about her schedule, I talk to Curtis and all I get are monosyllables, so -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think-he's really looking forward to it -- KARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh? Well, you know, that hasn't really  been my impression. So, uh...I also think  it would be good to shelve the idea of your coming out here next year. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 144 151 CONTINUED: 151 KARL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like things are gonna start picking up for me in the Fall, which means I'm probably not gonna be around the house all that much, and since you and Annette detest each other, I don't, uh, I don't think that's what I want to come home to after a fourteen hour day. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't detest each other KARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, well, it doesn't really strike me as something you're that serious about anyway, so what do you say we just table it for the time being? LISA

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: KARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. So tell Curtis, uh, that New Mexico's off...Ummm, and I will talk to you, ummm, whenever. LISA

dialogues.speaker: OK...
dialogues.text: KARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He hangs up. LISA hangs up too. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's cancelling the trip. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Why? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's says nobody wants to go and he doesn't want to spend the money. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say you didn't want to go? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I know there was some problem with Annette about arranging for food because I don't eat dead animals, but.I didn't think it was.going to wreck the whole trip. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 145 151 CONTINUED: (2) 151 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said it sounded like it was  going to be a disaster. Personally I'm relieved. I'm not moving out there, either, by the way, obviously. Which is fine too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl sits holding the phone in a savage depression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa sits on a sofa. She takes a sip of coffee. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for letting me come up. I don't know who else to talk to. She's talking to MR AARON, who looks very uncomfortable. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've always been very sympathetic to my craziness, and I may not show it all the time, but I actually really appreciate it. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no problem, Lisa. What's been going on? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need to talk to somebody who doesn't completely misunderstand who Iam. Or not even who I am, but what's going on inside me, or all around me. Sound confused enough? Anyway, for whatever reason, I always felt like we understood each other on some level, even though I'm like a mass of conflicting impulses and you're basically the most grown-up, rational man I know. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I doubt that's actually true but thank you... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem pretty fuckin' rational to me. Like that seems to be your leading feature. I mean you obviously have a lot of pretty deep feelings...So when you're rational - just to finish my thought -- it's like this really interesting way of governing yourself.  (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 146 153 CONTINUED: 153 LISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't have to get all uncomfortable again: I'm not talking about what you think I'm talking about, because I know that subject is-off-limits. I'm talking about your soul, I guess, and how you feel you have to keep it in check all the time by being sensible. Do you know what I'm saying at all? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...We all have feelings, Lisa. I happen to believe that who you are comes out of how you deal with those feelings. Somebody makes you mad, you don't just pick up a gun and shoot them...Or if you do, that says something about who you are, and how you've been raised... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want to disillusion you, but we happen to be living in a world where that is what people do. More often than not. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true, Lisa. I think it's very sad that you see it that way. There's eight billion people alive in the world and you think they don't all want to kill someone once in a while? But they don't. Most of them. Or they see some person they -- (Pause) I think most people do try to be  civilized by some standard. Even if it's a standard you and I might not agree with... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I get it. That's actually the most hopeful thing anybody's said to me for a long time. I don't know why I take such a dire view of things, I really don't. She removes her jacket. She's wearing a small clingy T-sh LISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little hot...A little warm .Is this all right? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you allow smoking in your apartment? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can smoke. She gets her cigarettes out and lights one. He gets up an brings her an ashtray. They meet at the sofa and sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 147 153 CONTINUED: (2) 153 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your apartment. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She blows some smoke out and waves it away. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is terrible. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is? What's terrible? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just like you so much...(Smooths her ash on the ashtray.) Sorry. What a moron. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking her hand) Hey. Lisa. I'm your friend. And that's not gonna change. That's not gonna change. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Thank you. She kisses his hand a couple of times. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please just let me for a second. I like you so much. I like you so, so much. She kisses his hand more elaborately. He lets this go on. She lifts her head up and they kiss for real. After a mom she slides her hand onto his leg. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, look... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stop me yet, OK? They kiss some more. She bends down to unzip his fly. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 148 153 CONTINUED: (3) 153 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me for one second... She bends her head over his lap. He lets her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on their faces as they are have having sex on the s She freezes up and starts freaking out. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. It's OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should stop.  LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stop. It's OK.  MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, you don't have to keep asking me  that. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should stop. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, keep going...! She keeps pushing against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AT THE DOOR. She is leaving. He is burning with guilt and shame. Silence. Then: LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I can say is I better get a pretty fuckin' good grade in geometry this year. (Pause) Lighten up! I'm kidding. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I really didn't expect anything like this to happen. I'm really not sure how to react. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'm not gonna tell anybody if that's what you're worried about. I totally initiated the whole thing.  (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 149 155 CONTINUED: 155 LISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, it's just sex. You're acting like a  little kid. I'll see you in school. She walks out. He is very flummoxed.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER IN BUS CRASH HAD RECORD OF PREVIOUS
dialogues.text: ACCIDENTS. The driver of a city bus which killed an Upper West Side woman last month had two previous driving violations on his record, according to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa and Emily sit in the office with Deutsch. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they want to settle. LISA & EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do...? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a meeting with their lawyer this afternoon, and they want to discuss a settlement. So we should get Abigail on the phone and talk about what-we're gonna do. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic. Lisa gets tears in her eyes and smiles, embarrassed. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK. 157

dialogues.speaker: INT. DEUTSCH'S OFFICE/INT. ABIGAIL'S HOUSE. LATER.
dialogues.text: They sit around the SPEAKER PHONE. Abigail's husband, ROB BERWITZ, is also on the other end. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Deutsch? Mr --  DEUTSCH ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm right here. I just had the thought -- ABIGAIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Deutsch -- I'm just gonna give my  husband the floor because he had a few QUESTIONS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revised 10/7/05 - Page 150 157 CONTINUED: 157 ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Deutsch, I had the thought, if they're willing to settle so quickly, maybe we're better off waiting a little bit, maybe rattling the sabre a little bit more... ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, if they're so quick to agree to a settlement on this basis -- DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you gotta realize -- What you gotta REALLY -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abigail, Russel doesn't think -- Sorry, go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ahead. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no...  EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend had a lot of trouble getting the one story placed in the paper as it is --  DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .Could I interject? ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if they responded so strongly based on one story... ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we're cuttin' our own throats here. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are responding to the story in the paper... ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .That's just common sense. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what you gotta understand is they're offering to settle now because they want to get the story out of the paper. EMILY LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why Russel thinks -- Besides, the main point is not to jack up the price. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- We didn't hear that last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revised 10/7/05 - Page 150A 157 CONTINUED: (2) 157 DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to EMILY and LISA) Ladies, let me just -- Abigail. Rob. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revised 10/7/05 - Page 151 157 CONTINUED: (3) 157 DEUTSCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could finish my thought -- They're jumpin' at the bait right now, but if another six months goes by we run a serious risk of losing our momentum. You see what I mean? Now I'm gonna hit 'em very very hard, I guarantee you. That's why I wanted all of us together on the phone, so we could talk about your other terms, besides the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: damages. I promise you, we'ere gonna be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: very very aggressive -- ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other terms would there be? ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, like some kind of a fund? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what? ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kind of fund? For the kids? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand what you mean by a fund... ROB ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to ABIGAIL) Mr. Deutsch? Do you mean What does he mean, "besides some kind of trust fund, the damages?" a fund that would be set up by the bus company for EMILY our kids? For tax purposes? What fuckin' fund? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people are retarded. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I have to tell you we have just lived through that nightmare with Monica and our children, and it was not a pleasant experience. We just want a clean, straight damages is fine. A regular payment. We'll pay the taxes on it. At least we'll have something in our hand... DEUSTCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really know what kind of fund you're talking about... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not talking about -- Hi, this is Lisa? We're ABIGAIL talking -- We're talking Hello, Lisa. about -- Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revised 10/7/05 - Page 152 157 CONTINUED: (4) 157

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're still here. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're talking about the driver, getting the driver fired -- ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as part of the conditions. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Abigail, it's very important to us that the company know that's an absolute pre-condition to making any kind of settlement whatsoever. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Absolutely. If you think he's at FAULT -- ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as long as they don't think they can buy us off just by gettin' rid of this guy. You see what I mean? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we're most concerned about here is the amount. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we're getting that, Rob. ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you see what I mean? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- Rob? Yes I do. ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to go on record as saying I think this whole meeting is premature. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. We're not lawyers -- DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abigail? Rob? I just wanna make something clear. One conversation does not commit you to anything. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revised 10/7/05 - Page 152A 157 CONTINUED: (5) 157 DEUTSCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm not gonna agree to anything without consulting you. But I'm working for you. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 153 157 CONTINUED: (6) 157 DEUTSCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if you're telling me not to take the meeting I'm not gonna take the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: No. We're not saying that. No no no -- Go for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa has just told Joan the news. Joan is on the sofa. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, I'm really proud of you! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, really proud...! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Pause. Joan gets to her feet and starts tidying up. LISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you upset about something...? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This house is really beginning to get to me. And I'm a little confused what to do about Ramon. I mean, you were there: What do you think? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, gee, Mom maybe you should really think about it some more. Because it would probably hurt Ramon's feelings if you broke up with him and I think you better think about it before you do something like that to him. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I'm supposed to understand what you're doing right now, but if there's some kind of hidden message here I'm not getting it. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit. You're on your own, Mom. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome. The PHONE RINGS. Joan picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 154 158 CONTINUED: 158 JOAN (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? -Yes . WHAT DO YOU MEAN?? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? JOAN (LISTENING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? . Yes? (To LISA) Ramon had a heart attack. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Is he gonna be --  JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: uiet!  CURTIS appears. They both watch Joan at the phone. Instea of dissolving, Joan listens, straightens up and calms dow the person on the phone talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mourners are going inside the funeral parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Lisa look around the room. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, I'm really not trying to be funny, but isn't this a Jewish funeral home? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess they do both.  They notice a few too many good-looking women crying a li too hard. Lisa and Joan look at each other.  RODRIGO, a handsome slender kid of 20, comes up to Joan. accent is British, with a slight Colombian cadence. RODRIGO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Joan? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You must be Rodrigo. Oh my God, oh I'm so sorry. She impulsively embraces him. JOAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo, this is my --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 155 160 CONTINUED: 160 RODRIGO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to tell you, Joan, my Dad talked about you all the time. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did? RODRIGO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The night he met you, he called me in England and woke me to tell me about it, he was so excited. I never heard him talk about anyone like that since my mother died. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  RODRIGO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if this is appropriate...  JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's OK...! RODRIGO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .but he went out a lot. Do you know the  last time I spoke to him he told me from  the moment he met you he knew he wanted to marry you, because for the first time since  he lost my mother, he finally met a woman he could really connect with. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at a total loss) Well -- he was a very sweet man. And I know he loved you and your brother very much. RODRIGO (GETTING TEARFUL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know he did. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa is at her computer. Joan is by the doorway. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming with me today. I really appreciate it. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're welcome. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be macabre, but Ramon and I were supposed to go to hear The Tales of Hoffman the week after next and I still have the tickets. Would you be interested in going? Or should I give them away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Pink Revised 11/17/05 - Page 156 161 CONTINUED: 161 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I'll go. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. It's Monday night. We can dress up. LISA

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you make of that? LISA (STILL TYPING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People don't relate to each other, Mom. They're totally disconnected. And if they have any time for each other at all, it's either like a biological imperative or like some weird cultural anomaly. That's what I make of it. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I think it's pretty unfortunate that you think that. Because I feel like you and I used to relate to each other really well. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to hurt your feelings. It's just a general observation. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK...Hey, could I get a hug? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Lisa rises and hugs Joan. It's not a good hug. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel totally at sea.  They break apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Aaron and Lisa sit in a booth. Mr Aaron looks grim. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've thought about this a great deal, and I'm going to come forward. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh brother. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Pink Revised 11/17/05 - Page 156A 162 CONTINUED: 162 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You're gonna come forward." And do what? You didn't kill anybody. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 157 162 CONTINUED: (2) 162 LISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just had sex with me after I practically begged you to. You're a guy. "I'm gonna come forward." MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's what I'm comfortable doing. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. I'll deny everything and you're gonna look like a total psycho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then my Mom'11 have you arrested, and then spend the rest of her life feeling bad about it. So why don't we just skip the whole thing and forget about it? MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I know how to do that. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa looks at a pregnancy test stick. Both lines are red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan looks up as Lisa comes in. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Lisa are looking at the little stick. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. What do you want to do? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Aren't JOAN you going to tell me. It's your body. It's your what to do? (half- baby. What do you want to do? laughing) Baby... .? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Now who is the father? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be a lot of people. Joan looks at her. Lisa haltingly holds her ground. Joan takes a sympathetic step toward her. Lisa shrinks back. J stops. Her expression hardens. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 158 165 CONTINUED: 165 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm never gonna tell you, Mom! It's against my principles! Such as they are. JOAN (ON "SUCH")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but you want to send that bus driver to jail for running a red light! And you won't tell me about these boys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan waits. She looks around the small room. There are tw couples and two lone women. A NURSE appears. NURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cohen? TRACKING Joan as she gets up and follows the Nurse down a hall... NURSE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .she's still a little woozy from the anaesthetic... Joan goes into the recovery room. Lisa is on the table in crumpled paper robe, looking like a small crumpled piece paper herself. Joan sits down. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi honey. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mom. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about it later. 167 INT. DEUTSCH'S OFFICE. DAY. Deutsch sits with Emily and Lisa. The Berwitzes are on th speaker phone. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very pleased to be able to inform you all that I had a long meeting with the lawyer for the bus company, and they've agreed to settle out of court for three hundred and fifty thousand dollars. ABIGAIL & ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! Fantastic! That's wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 159 167 CONTINUED: 167 DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm assuming this is agreeable to EVERYBODY -- ABIGAIL ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, fantastic That is fantastic!  DEUTSCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I gotta -- obviously I gotta bring the offer to you, get your approval -- ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Deutsch...? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I know there was a concern after our

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: last call that we were jumping the gun a little bit -- ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK -- ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're only -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abigail? Rob? If we could just listen to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: what Russel has to say, and then talk about it once he's told us the whole story and given us his recommendation... ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Sorry. Fire away. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gonna say I know there was a concern

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: after our last call that we were jumping the gun a little bit -- ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK -- ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you let him talk please?! DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're sorry. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to tell you I think it's a very good offer. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 160 167 CONTINUED: (2) 167 DEUTSCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're very anxious to settle, but I also do think that at this moment they're under the maximum amount of pressure we can really bring to bear, and I don't believe they're gonna come up any higher -- ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Three hundred and fifty thousand  dollars... ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, now let me just -- ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .that's nothin' to sneeze at. ROB ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to introduce Now, 1 think -- Can the thought -- you all hear me?

dialogues.speaker: DEUTSCH, EMILY, LISA
dialogues.text: Yes! ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeow! Was that everybody? OK: LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about -- ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Emily? What do you think? EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it sounds like we should do it. But I'd like to discuss some of the -- ABIGAIL (ON "BUT")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, if that's the vote... ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you think there's something to be gained from holding out for more. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it would be a big mistake. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie, what do you think? ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sold! ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 161 167 CONTINUED: (3) 167 DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Now the only down side to this as it stands -- and the reason I asked Emily and Lisa to be here is because I know this may be a serious wrinkle for you all -- is that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the bus company will absolutely not discuss the removal of the driver. LISA & EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver? LISA EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then forget it. Tell them to What do you mean they forget it. won't discuss the removal of the driver?  DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Ladies. Let me ROB finish what I'm saying. Whoa -- hello! ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a blast in our ears. EMILY (TO LISA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him finish. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish what? Forget it! DEUTSCH (TO EMILY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I want you to understand, Lisa, I pressed them very very hard on this, but they will not discuss disciplining of a company employee as part of the settlement because it could be seen as an admission of guilt on the part of the MTA -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does giving us three hundred thousand dollars mean?  DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settling out of court does not imply an admission of guilt. It simply does not carry the same stigma. On top of that you may not know, Lisa, they're involved in a very tricky labor dispute at the MTA right NOW:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 162 167 CONTINUED: (4) 167 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we know all about that! Just tell them to forget it.' DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that's your reaction... LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only reason we're here. ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I jump in here? Russel?  DEUTSCH  (TO LISA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .but it's really not your decision. ROB ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Are you still with us? Please! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Emily's decision. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not? ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not listening, Robbie. DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Abigail's decision because she's the next of kin. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she didn't even know about it! EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't matter. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we get back in this conversation please? DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm sorry. Obviously there's some very strong emotions going either way on this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 163 167 CONTINUED: (5) 167 ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Emily? I don't know what you're thinking, but Rob and I are thinking we should take Russel's recommendation while we can. Because if they won't fire the guy, they're not gonna fire him. And six months or a year from now we're gonna -- ROB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: we're gonna be in a situation where we're beggin' them for half this much, which is gonna hurt 'em half as much as now, and they're still not gonna fire this guy! Or maybe he'll have already quit and the whole thing will be moot by then.. Do you see what I mean? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire point of the lawsuit was to get the guy fired so he doesn't kill somebody else -- ! DEUTSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme just clarify -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- it was not to get you three hundred and fifty thousand dollars you didn't know you were entitled to, for somebody you didn't even like... ! ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a distortion -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the only reason you're getting the money at all is because I started this whole fucking thing in motion! I'm sorry for swearing, but you should be willing to trade in all the money for getting this guy off the street -- EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For getting him, Abigail! ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm sorry, but I have a responsibility to Monica and I take that responsibility very seriously. You are talking about an offer that is gonna be withdrawn if we don't do something about it right now. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 164 167 CONTINUED: (6) 167 ABIGAIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And rather than being abused over the telephone and cursed at for having the courtesy to involve you in these discussions, Lisa, I would hope you would be guided by our judgement. Unless I'm wrong about that. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of that matters -- ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless I'm wrong about that. Just what is your interest in this? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm the one who killed her! I'm the one who killed her! But at least I know I did it, and that guy has no idea! And he's wandering around blaming everybody else and all I want is for somebody to let him know that what he did was wrong! And if they don't fire him and all you want is the money and the police won't do anything, how is he gonna know he's wrong? You can't take the deal, Abigail! It wasn't so you could get any money, it was because we wanted to get him fired! It doesn't matter about the money! You wouldn't have gotten it before! ABIGAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it may not matter to you, but where I come from three hundred and fifty thousand dollars is an awful lot of money, and to my mind is a positive result of all this tragedy and not just negative. Not just getting someone fired for one mistake, no matter how bad it was -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh SHOVE IT UP YOUR ASS! She knocks the speaker phone off the desk and runs to the door in floods of tears. DEUTSCH & EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa! LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sleazy fucking lawyer! And you're a moralistic cunt! She runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING in front of Lisa as she walk-runs down the busy street. A city bus appears behind her and goes by. She cr to see the driver. It's not her guy. She keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa stands against a car, smoking, as the kids flow out the building. Mr Aaron comes out, talking with BONNIE, th gymnastics teacher. They walk away from the school togeth Lisa catches up with them. BONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Lisa. What's Up? - LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, did you guys know I had an abortion last week? Pause. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I didn't know that. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it cost four hundred dollars. BONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, should I... MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, don't go anywhere. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, don't go anywhere. Bonnie doesn't know what to make of this. Mr Aaron looks steadily at Lisa. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to tell us about it? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I do. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. -Go ahead. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... She doesn't speak. Pause. BONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do your parents know about this, Lisa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 166 169 CONTINUED: 169 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. BONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you told the father, honey? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...There's a couple of people it could be. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you better tell them. Whoever they are. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...No...Never mind ...I'm sure he's sorry anyway, whichever one he is. MR AARON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see what difference that makes, if he's sorry. And I think whoever it is should know about this. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I shouldn't have brought this up. Please don't tell anyone. BONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not gonna tell anyone. But you're gonna have to tell whoever it could be -- LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On have to") That's OK. I gotta go. Thanks for listening. It's -- It doesn't matter about the father, because the whole thing was my fault. I'm sorry...! She shakes her head and runs away. BONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa comes in. Curtis is doing his homework at the table. CURTIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom's looking for you. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? CURTIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks you're going out with her tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 167 170 CONTINUED: 170 LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going? CURTIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Lisa heads for her room. Joan appears, half-dressed. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa? Honey? Did you forget we're going to the opera? LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't-remind you because I didn't want to nag you. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa starts to cross the street against the light. Joan t her arm. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get run over. A cab rattles by. Lisa looks down the street. A BUS is approaching. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. I want to see if that's him. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. They wait. The bus gets closer, heading straight toward t and stops at the bus stop. Lisa grabs her mother's arm. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is him. Mom, that's the one... Joan and Lisa look at him. He's staring out ahead of him people board the bus. He SEES Lisa and Joan but can't see their faces and doesn't recognize Lisa: He just sees two dolled-up women under the street light. He smiles dazzlin them and drives past with a short wave. Joan looks at Lisa. She looks like she's about to throw u JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. We're gonna miss the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa is out on the terrace smoking a cigarette, looking o over Lincoln Center. Joan comes out and stands next to he but Lisa won't look at her or interact. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, so far it's not the greatest opera I ever heard. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? It's OK. The end-of-intermission chimes sound. People start going Joan turns and goes in too. Lisa keeps smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa comes down the stairs and goes into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa hurries down the long aisle. The LIGHTS DIM. The  audience applauds the entering conductor. She picks her w past the other patrons in the row, whispering "Excuse me" takes her seat just as the MUSIC STARTS. Joan looks at he Lisa stares straight ahead.  The curtain rises. On stage, the two women start singing barcarole "Belle Nuit." It's very beautiful. Joan looks next to her at Lisa. Lisa is trying not to cry but tears are dripping slowly down her face. She sniffs a wipes them away, but they keep coming. Joan looks at her again, but Lisa still won't look at her Joan takes Lisa's hand and Lisa breaks down completely, clutching Joan's hand back, squeezing it hard. Joan start crying too out of sympathy. As the duet goes on they sit side by side holding hands, crying and holding on and wiping her eyes with her free h and Joan crying too, but not as hard, grateful finally th the spell has been broken. The duet ends and we CUT TO BLACK. THE END
